The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including
        administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4.	The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
5.	The five-year accident history
6.	The emergency response program
7.	Planned changes to improve safety


A-1	 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Mercer Foods is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Mercer Foods has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours. State regulations require reporting when there is a significant release or a threat of a significant release of ammonia or other hazardous material.  Mercer Foods interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedures that may prevent future incidents.

Any release may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia systems or portions of the system depe

nding on the location of the release. All releases or emergencies will be reported immediately to management on site. The General Manager, Engineering Manager, Safety Manager and the Maintenance Manager are to be called if not on site for support.  Incidential releases will be  handled in house. Substantial releases will be handled jointly between Mercer Foods and local responders.

The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment on an ongoing basis and prior to startup of modified or new processes. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel, registered engineers, refrigeration experts, and certified refrigeration contractors as required review the equipment and process.

There are additional full time Managers and operational employees at this facility in addition to the Maintenance that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems on a regular basis. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately. An example would be excessive rust on piping or tanks. This team activity is the core of Mercer Foods prevention program.  


A-2	STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The refrigeration system/process is a direct, closed loop, mechanical refrigeration system. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the Main Plant Refrigeration System (Process 1) and is the only regulated substance.

Mercer Foods Ammonia Process operates 24/7.

The facility is located in the city of Modesto in an industrial/commercial area.

A-3 	HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst

-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition the Main Plant Systems are separated by walls and distance. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

A-4	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Mercer Foods Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by Mercer Foods is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of Mercer Foods Prevention Program are briefly described below:
1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Mercer Foods.  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements).

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  Mercer Foods certifies operators following completion of operator training and Mercer Foods's confirmation of the operator's ability apply what they have learned.  (Addressed und

er Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Mercer Foods employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation Element)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Mercer Foods's Management of Change Procedure. 
 
If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contracts, Mercer Foods has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other Hot Work occurs close to the refrigeration system, a Mercer Foods Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 

Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work Permit, and Pre-Start-up Safety Review Elements.)

7) Verification of Mercer Foods's compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program (and t

he Risk Management Program) has been implemented and properly documented by Mercer Foods personnel.  Mercer Foods has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under Mercer Foods's Injury and Illness Prevention Program)

INJURY AND ILLINESS/ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility follows the EPA's 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process Safety Management Program.  In addition the plan satisfies the State of California's Injury and Illness Prevention Program requirements CCR Title 8 3203. In California, every employer is required by law to provide a safe and healthful workplace to his/her employees. In accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Mercer Foods has an effective written Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP). 
The IIPP is a written plan that covers the following elements:
 	Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 
 	Safety communications system with employees 
 	System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 
 	Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 
 	Accident investigation 
 	Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 
 	Safety and health training and instruction 
 	Recordkeeping and documentation 

The IIPP includes procedures that Mercer Foods personnel must put into practice. It is both the employer's and employee's responsibility to control potential workplace hazards and correct hazardous conditions or practices as they occur or are recognized. The program includes a system for personnel to communicate with management on matters relating to occupational safety and health, including provisions designed to encourage employees to inform the management of hazards at the worksite without fear of reprisal.
The safety communications system, one of the elements of the IIPP, is readily available and understa

ndable to all affected employees. 
The safety communication system includes:
 	Meetings 
 	Training programs 
 	Postings 
 	Written communications 
 	A system for anonymous notification by employees about hazards 
 	Labor/management safety and health committees 
 	Tail gate or tool box meetings
In addition to the above, during Construction the IIPP requires that Manager's conduct toolbox or tailgate safety meetings with their crews at least every ten working days to empha safety. Managers also need to hold periodic meetings to discuss safety problems and accidents that have occurred.
The completed IIPP is filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices

Program Consolidation

The documentation requirements of these programs have been consolidated in the documenting and record filing process. The documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program for the current year and then archived in the current year archive binder.
The following identifies the practices and procedures for:
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training
Mechanical Integrity
Management of Change
Pre-Startup Review
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigations
Employee Participation
Hot Works
Contractors

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as MSDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipmen

t specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

See the Prevention Program Element 1 for the complete information
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the What-if checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

See Element 2 of the Prevention Program for the complete guidelines
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office 

Technical Operating Specifications and Standard Operating Procedures
The Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) and Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) are provided for each compressor, condenser, ammonia vessel, oil pot, and evaporator etc. Topics include general information such items as;
¿	Objectives 
¿	Special hazards 
¿	Location 
¿	Safety equipment needed 
¿	P&ID's  and Block Flow Diagrams
¿	Technical operating specifications, 
¿	Electrical classifications 
¿	Step-by-step procedures
¿	Specific warnings & PPE 

The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety programs and procedures are included.

See the Prevention Program Element 3 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods

Training
All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding

the MSDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan or action plan.

See the Prevention Program Element 4 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Human Resources Office.

Mechanical Integrity
The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity Audit program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition. Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps etc.

See the Prevention Program Element 5 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Management of Change
The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even replacement in kind) be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

See the Prevention Program Element 6 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Pre-Startup Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

See the Prevention Program Element 7 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed d

ocuments are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Compliance Audits
To insure that all sections of the PSM program are up to date and followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years. Resubmission of the RMP shall be done according to requirements.

See the Prevention Program Element 8 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Incident Investigation
An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

See the Prevention Program Element 9 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.
Employee Participation
The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire dep

artment and CUPA.

See the Prevention Program Element 10 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices
This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. The Maintenance Manager reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operations.

See the Prevention Program Element 11 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

Contractors and Contractor Qualifications
This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 

See the Prevention Program Element 12 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Mercer Foods Office.

A-5	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years that meet the standard of State or Federal regulations.  

A-6	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as:

The facilities emergency response plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills, attendance at Ammonia Safety Days and on site drills. Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responding facility personnel.  All areas (zones) inside the building can be brought under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel are on site.  Incidental releases can be brought under control immediately. 
 
The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shut down or isolation valves and controls for the system, component or zone with the release.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches are identified at the facility.  

For Hazardous Materials Responders do not enter an IDLH condition. Responders are trained to the Air Purifying Respirator level and trained to retreat at (300 PPM or less) for ammonia. Facility responders will assist outside agencies during larger releases. All visitors, drivers and contractors will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for by the area supervisor and or person visited. Personnel not trained to respond will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for by area supervisors or managers

The Federal and Cali

fornia and Federal Emergency Planning Regulations considered in this program include:
	EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP)
	OSHA's Emergency Action Plan
	OSHA's Process Safety Standard
	EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know
	Contingency Plan
	California Code of Regulations: Health and Safety Codes including 
        CCR Title 8 and Title 19 (CalARP)
        Modesto County Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP)

A-7	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
